factoid: The oasis of the Otrádnoe covert was sighted a few hundred yards away.
The huntsmen were already approaching the oasis of the Otrádnoe covert.
Rostóv settled with “Uncle” at the location where they should set on the hounds.
Rostóv showed Natásha the spot where she was to stand.
Uncle told Rostóv: "Well, nephew, you’re going for a big wolf."
Uncle told Rostóv: "Mind and don’t let her slip!"
Rostóv replied: "That’s as may happen."
Rostóv shouted: "Karáy, here!"
Karáy is a shaggy old dog with a hanging jowl.
Karáy is famous for tackling a big wolf unaided.
The group took up their places.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was an old count.
Count Ilyá Rostóv knew his son’s ardor in the hunt.
Count Ilyá Rostóv hurried so as not to be late.
The huntsmen had not yet reached their places when Count Ilyá Rostóv arrived.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was cheerful, flushed, and had quivering cheeks.
Count Ilyá Rostóv drove up with his black horses over the winter rye to the place reserved for him.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was at a place where a wolf might come out.
Count Ilyá Rostóv straightened his coat and fastened his hunting knives and horn.
Count Ilyá Rostóv mounted his horse Viflyánka.
Viflyánka was turning gray, like Count Ilyá Rostóv.
Count Ilyá Rostóv’s horses and trap were sent home.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was not a keen sportsman at heart.
Count Ilyá Rostóv knew the rules of the hunt well.
Count Ilyá Rostóv rode to the bushy edge of the road where he was to stand.
Count Ilyá Rostóv arranged his reins, settled in the saddle, and looked about with a smile.
Beside Count Ilyá Rostóv was Simon Chekmár, his personal attendant.
Simon Chekmár was an old horseman somewhat stiff in the saddle.
Simon Chekmár held in leash three formidable wolfhounds.
The wolfhounds had grown fat like their master and his horse.
Two wise old dogs lay down unleashed.
Mítka, the count’s other groom, stood some hundred paces farther along the edge of the wood.
Mítka was a daring horseman and keen rider to hounds.
Before the hunt, Count Ilyá Rostóv drank a silver cupful of mulled brandy.
Count Ilyá Rostóv took a snack before the hunt.
Count Ilyá Rostóv washed his drink down with half a bottle of his favorite Bordeaux.
Count Ilyá Rostóv was somewhat flushed with wine and the drive.
Count Ilyá Rostóv’s eyes were rather moist and glittered more than usual.
Count Ilyá Rostóv sat in his saddle wrapped up in his fur coat and looked like a child taken out for an outing.
Simon Chekmár kept glancing at Count Ilyá Rostóv, with whom he had lived on the best of terms for thirty years.
Simon Chekmár expected a pleasant chat with Count Ilyá Rostóv.
A third person rode up circumspectly through the wood and stopped behind Count Ilyá Rostóv.
The third person was a gray-bearded old man in a woman’s cloak with a tall peaked cap on his head.
The third person was the buffoon who went by a woman’s name, Nastásya Ivánovna.
Count Ilyá Rostóv whispered: "Well, Nastásya Ivánovna!" and winked at him.
Count Ilyá Rostóv said: "If you scare away the beast, Daniel’ll give it you!"
Nastásya Ivánovna said: "I know a thing or two myself!"
Count Ilyá Rostóv whispered: "Hush!" and turned to Simon Chekmár.
Count Ilyá Rostóv asked Simon Chekmár: "Have you seen the young countess?"
Count Ilyá Rostóv asked Simon Chekmár: "Where is she?"
Simon Chekmár answered: "With young Count Peter, by the Zhárov rank grass."
Simon Chekmár said: "Though she’s a lady, she’s very fond of hunting."
Count Ilyá Rostóv asked Simon Chekmár: "And you’re surprised at the way she rides, Simon, eh?"
Simon Chekmár said: "She’s as good as many a man!"
Simon Chekmár said: "Of course! It’s marvelous. So bold, so easy!"
Simon Chekmár asked: "And Nicholas? Where is he? By the Lyádov upland, isn’t he?"
Simon Chekmár answered: "Yes, sir. He knows where to stand. He understands the matter so well that Daniel and I are often quite astounded."
Simon Chekmár said: "Rides well, eh? And how well he looks on his horse, eh?"
Simon Chekmár said: "A perfect picture! How he chased a fox out of the rank grass by the Zavárzinsk thicket the other day!"
Simon Chekmár said: "Leaped a fearful place; what a sight when they rushed from the covert."
Simon Chekmár said: "The horse was worth a thousand rubles and the rider beyond all price."
Simon Chekmár said: "Yes, one would have to search far to find another as smart."
